ovdesc.p: This static table is used to record additional information necessary for the Securities module to identify the capacity in which a counterparty is acting.
There are five different categories of bank "Customer" which the system will recognise.
The concept of this table is to restrict and control these "Customers" to specific transactions within the operating sphere of the Securities' module.
The "Customer" may well act as one of the following:
Customer: Client: Broker: Counterparty: Depository:
Whenever a securities transaction is entered, T24 will first check within this table to ensure that the bank "Customer" has been opened in accordance with the capacity in which he is acting.
This allows the management to specify and control their approved list of brokers and depositories for example.
A portfolio account (SEC.ACC.MASTER) cannot be opened for a "Customer" unless this table has been updated with the value "Customer".

"Client", "Broker" & "Counterparty" are to all intents and purposes equal when it comes to processing transactions. However the text of any output (Advices,Telexs etc) can be customised in accordance with local regulations thanks to the different values which can be attributed against these "Customers".
For example the wording on documents can be set up to highlight the difference between principal and agency type transactions.
The main application for buying and selling securities within this module is SEC.TRADE, this can best be divided into three distinct areas.
The first is concerned with the security being traded.
The second part of the transaction is dedicated to buying and selling securities for a portfolio customer.
The agent with whom this is done can belong to one of the three categories already mentioned.
Whilst the second part of the SEC.TRADE is dedicated to a clients' portfolio holding it is not a prerequisite to settle a trade.

A trade can be entered between a "Broker" and a "Client" for example and providing the amount of securities being sold is equivalent to the amount being bought then the integrity of the system is maintained and the deal will be accepted.
Local practice will however restrict this type of operation and insist on securites being booked into and out of trading accounts.
It has always been the action of the customer which has decided the type of transaction being entered on the Broker side.
The system is happy to accept the fact that a purchase of securities for a client involves adding charges, commissions etc., to the gross cost of the transaction.
The corresponding sale of securites by the "Broker" still involves commissions and charges being added to the gross amount to be paid.

Even though we now could have a situation where we have entered a "Client" selling shares in the second part of the SEC.TRADE application the system will now consider him as the agent doing the selling and will deduct charges and commissions from the net amount due to be paid to him. Likewise the counterparty who will be buying the shares involved in this transaction will deduct commissions and charges from the amount that he will pay.

The third and probably most important component of a banks' relationship with its "Customers" is that of the "Depository". Which is responsible for the safecustody and delivery of a banks' securities.
Within T24 each individual client holding is linked to a depository record.

When processing a transaction the system will validate that there are sufficient holdings in any one particular security by customer/depository. If not it will prompt the user with an override message. Depending on his level of access in accordance with the SMS facility the user may accept the override.

It is important to understand the consequences of such actions on an integrated system such as T24. On authorisation of the transaction delivery and receipt instructions will be generated via several mediums; Telex, Swift, Euclid, Clearstream etc. Insufficient securites will cause the settlement to fail and will lead to interest claims and additional work in correcting the mistake. T24 will prevent this, and the eventuality of short positions being created.

It is the depository which generates the settlement instructions to the numerous clearing agencies used world wide. This is why we maintain the importance of this relationship with individual customer holdings when processing transactions.

A client could well act in all three capacities and there is suitable allowance made for this by means of multi valued fields within the same file.

This field contains the CEDEL counterparty number of the T24 Client.
For a complete description of the clearing mechanism within the T24 Securities module see "Securities Delivery" manual.
A T24 user may set up several "Clearing Systems" within the Securities module. Two such examples are CEDEL and EUROCLEAR.

The manner and format of any interface between these clearing houses and the T24 user would obviously have to be defined and possibly additional programming included. As T24 is SWIFT dedicated the possibility of using EUROCLEAR SWIFT to settle via CEDEL already exists.
As there are numerous components required within any SWIFT message it is important that, wherever possible, default information is available and can be used when processing transactions.
Recognising CEDEL as a clearing agent, T24 creates the type of message defined for that transaction. This may have been a delivery "Free of Payment" or "Against Payment".

T24 needs to inform CEDEL of the ID of the counterparty within CEDEL along with other CEDEL related information e.g. the CEDEL code number the security. If it cannot find either of these two pieces of information then it will advise the user at transaction level.
It should be part of the implementation strategy to include both pieces of information when setting-up the initial database and any subsequent data.

SEC.TRADE is an "intelligent" transaction processor and has validation rules concerning the various types of deals being entered; for a fuller explanation of these validation rules see the "Securities Delivery" manual.

The only allowable formats are; '5 Numerics', '1 alpha 4 numerics', '1numeric1alpha 3numerics' or '1numeric 1alpha 1numeric 1 alpha 1numeric.' (Optional input) Standard CEDEL counterparty code which must be unique.

Field to determine whether consolidated nostro entry should be generated. Nostro aggregation cannot be set as yes without trade and settle aggregation in order to cater for full reconciliation. Setting of Nostro reconciliation will create aggregated trade between aggregated portfolio setup in SC.STD.SEC.TRADE and actual broker. Entry will be raised between aggregated suspense account and broker nostro.
Allowed value is YES

When STK.EXC.AGGREGATE is set as YES then the fields TRADE.AGGREGATION, SETTLE.AGGREGATION and NOSTRO.AGGREGATION will be set as YES if they are null. This field will determine whether aggregation setup in stock exchange should also be checked. If this field is not set, Aggregation will be performed if set at broker level. If this field is set to yes, Aggregation will be performed only if aggregation is also enabled at stock exchange level.
